fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This bicategory has initial and terminal objects.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Kleisli category induces the initial decomposition of a monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Kleisli category together with its canonical adjunction is the initial decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Eilenberg–Moore category induces the terminal decomposition of a monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Eilenberg–Moore category together with its canonical adjunction is the terminal decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors. Hence there is a unique morphism from any decomposition to it, named the comparison functor.
Given a pair of adjoint functors F \dashv G, G is monadic if the corresponding comparison functor to \mathcal { C } ^{G \circ F} is an equivalence in the bicategory of decompositions.

A monad on a category \mathcal { C } is a functor M : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { C } equipped with natural transformations \eta : \operatorname {Id} \to M and \mu : M \circ M \to M satisfying identity and associativity laws. In an unbiased way, we have a family of natural transformations M^n \to M with associativity.
In short, it is a monoid in the category of endofunctors equipped with composition as the monoidal product.
Given a pair of adjoint functors F \dashv G, G is monadic if the corresponding comparison functor to \mathcal { C } ^{G \circ F} is an equivalence in the bicategory of decompositions.
